. Chromecast API has changed significantly. 
In order to get it working again we need to:
- Implement MDNS discovery (DIAL has be deprecated)
- Implement encryption of packets (mayor pain, because android API and web now check for certificate issuer)
- RAMP protocol has been extended and most of the old methods are no longer used (ping is the only one remaining)

Majal:
Question: What port and protocol is leapcast using?
I'm on Linux and am using ufw firewall. When disabled, the devices detects my computer. I wanted the firewall to be enabled though, and only open (allow) the port and protocol that leapcast uses. So then the question above.
Thanks!
. After a few minutes it was working...
And the answer is:
TCP port 8008
Thanks to:
netstat -n -A inet | grep 192\.168
and
lsof -i | grep leapcast

And the ufw rule should be:
sudo ufw allow 8008/tcp
.

inutt:
I've been looking into this on my HTPC recently. On linux, chrome tends to need the "--ignore-gpu-blacklist" flag to use hardware video acceleration.
Even if this is set in the "chrome://flags" page for the user that runs leapcast, it won't persist since leapcast launches chrome/chromium using a temporary user data dir, which sets up a new profile with no flags set.
I'm not familiar with how to do GitHub stuff at the moment, but modifying the command line used to launch chrome/chromium in leap_factory.py to include "--ignore-gpu-blacklist" enables full frame rate playback for me. The same goes for pointing leapcast at the already configured user data dir too, although then the window doesn't open fullscreen.
The first few seconds of a video are displayed at low quality with a temporary user data dir, which doesn't happen if I launch the browser using the usual user data dir, so I'm not sure if either is really a full solution.

normanr:
So I found the problem, SO_REUSEPORT and SO_REUSEADDR need to be set before bind: eg:
``` diff
diff --git a/leapcast/services/ssdp.py b/leapcast/services/ssdp.py
index 4cc1b70..a4bac07 100644
--- a/leapcast/services/ssdp.py
+++ b/leapcast/services/ssdp.py
@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@ class MulticastServer(ControlMixin, ThreadingUDPServer):
         self.socket.setsockopt(socket.IPPROTO_IP, socket.IP_MULTICAST_LOOP,
                                mode)

def handle_membership(self, cmd):
def server_bind(self):
         try:
             if hasattr(socket, "SO_REUSEADDR"):
                 self.socket.setsockopt(
@@ -44,7 +44,9 @@ class MulticastServer(ControlMixin, ThreadingUDPServer):
                     socket.SOL_SOCKET, socket.SO_REUSEPORT, 1)
         except Exception as e:
             logging.log(e)

ThreadingUDPServer.server_bind(self)


def handle_membership(self, cmd):
         if self._listen_interfaces is None:
             mreq = struct.pack(
                 str("4sI"), socket.inet_aton(self._multicast_address[0]),
``

GundamWing:
It looks like the https://clients3.google.com/cast/chromecast/device/config location is no longer the authority for returning a list of enabled services. It still lists all the pre-final-SDK services for backward compatibility, but doesn't contain any new ones.
. Looks like the new location is https://clients3.google.com/cast/chromecast/device/baseconfig The file still has all the old entries, but now has a generic "enabled_app_ids" field that contains a list of approved apps. Seems the old way of doing things is over. There must be a query later that gets the custom launch URL or tells it to use the built in media receiver or the styled version. Chrome is still at the core and the js libraries for the receivers should still be accessible, so leapcast will probably still work once the new discovery mechanism is figured out and coded in.
. Looks like Google killed the DIAL discovery mechanism in the final SDK too. No broadcast is going to 239.255.255.250 any longer DIAL discovery. I had to resort to packet sniffing after I updated the leap.py code to deal with the new "enabled_app_ids" way of getting their information. Leapcast never sees a DIAL request so there's no activity as far as it's concerned. 
. That's it. I was filtering DNS packets so that went under the radar. Thanks.  It does look like quite a bit got changed. I see the cv2 calls in the Chromecast debug log now along with the new mDNS mechanism.

. @GRMrGecko my understanding is that the chromecast uses a a hardware device like a TPM.
you don't just Reverse engineer that device.
Google would be able to pretty easily track if we just cloned a single certificate of a TPM (given that you're able to do that, which its job is to literally make sure that can't happen)
The other alternative is to break the certificate that was used to sign the certs, which is non-trivial as it likely has sufficient key length to be difficult.
and even if we did that, google would just issue a new cert and use that for all future devices until it can eventually phase out the old one.

grandrew:
Here is what official docs say about it:
- https://developers.google.com/cast/docs/audio
- https://developers.google.com/cast/docs/custom_receiver.html#capabilities
from the first doc it seems that it is not possible to stream audio only if the app is video+audio, and/or the app must somehow explicitly support streaming of audio only (I guess that youtube does that?)
the second doc seems to point that the only thing that distinguishes audio-only and video+audio devices is the CAST-DEVICE-CAPABILITIES: {"display_supported":false} header that should be sent with the request if there is no display support, and the app should take care of the rest. As far as I understand, this means that the chrome should be somehow instructed to attach this header to the request, and according to http://peter.sh/experiments/chromium-command-line-switches/ - there is no way to do this at commandline args.
.

dobrakmato:
I added these two lines to leapcast's main.py file:
import requests
requests.packages.urllib3.disable_warnings()
That disabled urllib3 warnings about SNI. Then I also added verify=False to services/leap.py:35 to make the library not raise error. 
```
load json-file
resp = requests.get(url=app_dict_url, verify=False)
```
